The motto of the "Hundred Slackers' Club" is "Loaf Until It
Hurts," and they earned special mention in the ticket campaign.

The Hollander Prize should do much to raise the standard of
college journalism at this University, not only this year, but in years
to come.
The News-Letter has, of course, no reward to offer its workers;
the work that is done for the sheet is done purely through college
spirit or through the love of literary work.
The men who are selected for the editorial staff of the paper are
chosen, not alone through ability to write, but in recognition of earnest, consistent and original work. The quality of the paper depends
upon the ability of the candidates from whom the editors are selected.
There is no doubt in our mind but that there could be brought together from the undergraduate body a board of editors with greater
literary ability than that possessed by the existent staff, but the fact
remains that this fictitious board is composed of "birds who won't
sing."
They have the ability, but either have not the ambition or do not
believe the game worth the candle. A Varsity Seal is the reward of
two years' service upon the editorial staff or election to the Board of
Control, but two years generally seems an eternity to the prospective
candidate.
The Hollander Prize should certainly draw forth the best from
among the ranks of Hopkins litterateurs.
Dr. Hollander has certainly proved himself an interested backer
of undergraduate activities, and in offering this prize has set an example that may be followed with good results, by the few alumni
readers who believe the quality of "young thought" to be on the de-

"Who Was yohn Hancock?"

THE HOLLANDER PRIZE

German

OHN HANCOCK was an American statesman and patriot.
His signature is found on the oldest and most important documents of Massachusetts, and of the United States. He was
the first signer of the Declaration of Independence and was the
first Governor of Massachusetts.
John Hancock was born at Quincy, Massachusetts, in 1737.
He graduated from Harvard College, and entering upon his
uncle's business became a successful merchant in Boston. He
gained much in social power and in wealth, being meanwhile
justly popular for his integrity and ability.
He was in 1765-1770 a selectman of Boston and a member of
the general court. With Samuel Adams he led the Massachusetts Whigs,and only escaped capture at Lexington and Concord
by virtue of the valiant fight by the Minute Men on the "Nineteenth of April in '75."
John Hancock was subsequently known in various positions:
as President of the Continental Congress, as Major-General of
the Massachusetts military forces, as President of the Constitutional Convention. He died at Quincy,Massachusetts,October
eighth, 1793.
The historical position of John Hancock is unique in State
and Nation. He wielded great political influence but was always
liberal and public-spirited. His name is most prominent as a
Whig leader during the American Revolution in such events
as the Boston Massacre, the Boston Tea Party and the battles
of Lexington and Concord.
John Hancock signed his name first to the Declaration of
Independence. He thus risked his own "life,liberty, and pursuit
of happiness"that these privileges might be obtained for others
to enjoy. To this end he "pledged his life, his fortune, and his
sacred honor."
That he was popular and efficient may be judged from the
fact that he was for ten years Governor of Massachusetts, being elected annually to this office by popular vote.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 11,
PRESIDENT OF STUDENT COUNCIL
SPEAKS TO FRESHMAN CLASS

"Dick" Wood, president of thc
Student Council, addressed the
Freshman Class, at their meeting
last Thursday, in regard to the attendance of Freshmen at the spring
sports.
"Dick" announced that the Student Council has not yet decided
upon any action to increase the
Freshmen attendance at the games.
He said that, if three-fourths of
the class were present at the next
few games, it would not be necessary to adopt any compulsory measures, but the Council will be obliged
to enforce attendance of the Freshmen if they do not turn out well.
Page O'Connor, the Frosh president, urged the class to show their
spirit and attend the games. He
also appointed "Bob" Skinner to
take charge of the men entering the
interclass track meet.
In the future, notices of Freshmen Class meetings will be posted
three days in advance, so as to assure good attendance.

The motto of the "Hundred Slackers' Club" is "Loaf Until It
Hurts," and they earned special mention in the ticket campaign.

The Hollander Prize should do much to raise the standard of
college journalism at this University, not only this year, but in years
to come.
The News-Letter has, of course, no reward to offer its workers;
the work that is done for the sheet is done purely through college
spirit or through the love of literary work.
The men who are selected for the editorial staff of the paper are
chosen, not alone through ability to write, but in recognition of earnest, consistent and original work. The quality of the paper depends
upon the ability of the candidates from whom the editors are selected.
There is no doubt in our mind but that there could be brought together from the undergraduate body a board of editors with greater
literary ability than that possessed by the existent staff, but the fact
remains that this fictitious board is composed of "birds who won't
sing."
They have the ability, but either have not the ambition or do not
believe the game worth the candle. A Varsity Seal is the reward of
two years' service upon the editorial staff or election to the Board of
Control, but two years generally seems an eternity to the prospective
candidate.
The Hollander Prize should certainly draw forth the best from
among the ranks of Hopkins litterateurs.
Dr. Hollander has certainly proved himself an interested backer
of undergraduate activities, and in offering this prize has set an example that may be followed with good results, by the few alumni

"Who Was yohn Hancock?"

THE HOLLANDER PRIZE

German

OHN HANCOCK was an American statesman and patriot.
His signature is found on the oldest and most important documents of Massachusetts, and of the United States. He was
the first signer of the Declaration of Independence and was the
first Governor of Massachusetts.
John Hancock was born at Quincy, Massachusetts, in 1737.
He graduated from Harvard College, and entering upon his
uncle's business became a successful merchant in Boston. He
gained much in social power and in wealth, being meanwhile
justly popular for his integrity and ability.
He was in 1765-1770 a selectman of Boston and a member of
the general court. With Samuel Adams he led the Massachusetts Whigs,and only escaped capture at Lexington and Concord
by virtue of the valiant fight by the Minute Men on the "Nineteenth of April in '75."
John Hancock was subsequently known in various positions:
as President of the Continental Congress, as Major-General of
the Massachusetts military forces, as President of the Constitutional Convention. He died at Quincy,Massachusetts,October
eighth, 1793.
The historical position of John Hancock is unique in State
and Nation. He wielded great political influence but was always
liberal and public-spirited. His name is most prominent as a
Whig leader during the American Revolution in such events
as the Boston Massacre, the Boston Tea Party and the battles
of Lexington and Concord.
John Hancock signed his name first to the Declaration of
Independence. He thus risked his own "life,liberty, and pursuit
of happiness"that these privileges might be obtained for others
to enjoy. To this end he "pledged his life, his fortune, and his
sacred honor."
That he was popular and efficient may be judged from the
fact that he was for ten years Governor of Massachusetts, being elected annually to this office by popular vote.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 11,
PRESIDENT OF STUDENT COUNCIL
SPEAKS TO FRESHMAN CLASS

"Dick" Wood, president of thc
Student Council, addressed the
Freshman Class, at their meeting
last Thursday, in regard to the attendance of Freshmen at the spring
sports.
"Dick" announced that the Student Council has not yet decided
upon any action to increase the
Freshmen attendance at the games.
He said that, if three-fourths of
the class were present at the next
few games, it would not be necessary to adopt any compulsory measures, but the Council will be obliged
to enforce attendance of the Freshmen if they do not turn out well.
Page O'Connor, the Frosh president, urged the class to show their
spirit and attend the games. He
also appointed "Bob" Skinner to
take charge of the men entering the
interclass track meet.
In the future, notices of Freshmen Class meetings will be posted
three days in advance, so as to assure good attendance.
